questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Heart failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? ( INICET NOV 2022) Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Parvo virus infection -
  • ➤ Parvo virus infection -
  • ➤ Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection
  • ➤ A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,
  • ➤ lacy erythematous rash,
  • ➤ "slapped cheek" rash
  • ➤ Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS ), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.
  • ➤ papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS
  • ➤ Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.
  • ➤ small joint arthropathy
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen in patients with immunosuppression.
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia
  • ➤ Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC ) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.
  • ➤ transient aplastic crisis (TAC
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss .
  • ➤ hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024) A. Amyl Nitrite B. Sodium Nitrite C. Sodium Thiosulphate D. Benzyl Thiocyanate E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? ( INICET May 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrease generation of reduced glutathione
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 185-186
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 185-186

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with an extremely painful blister characterized by a woody surface. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Necrotizing fasciitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe infection that affects the fascia and subcutaneous tissues, leading to extreme pain, blistering, and a woody surface, and requires prompt medical attention.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: B. Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high. Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option C. Glucose:
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Glucose:
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen. Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen. Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Relevance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers P i , uses PLP (B 6 ) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region . It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.
  • • sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region
  • • The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.
  • • The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) : The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII)
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. A diagnosis of cardiac tamponade is considered. Which of the following changes in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is most indicative of cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Y descent is blunted/absent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade, the Y descent on the jugular venous pressure waveform is blunted or absent due to restricted right ventricular filling during diastole.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sumatriptan, a vasoconstrictor, should not be given to patients with a history of coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction due to the risk of triggering serious cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adult ovary are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • ➤ Adult ovary
  • ➤ arrested in prophase I
  • ➤ After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes . Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.
  • ➤ It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -
  • • Argyll Robertson pupil,
  • • neurosyphilis.
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.
  • • The Near triad , consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.
  • • Near triad
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome : This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis
  • • Option C. Papilledema : This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.
  • • Option C. Papilledema
  • • swelling of the optic disc
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis : This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

questions.text: If any unsound minded person commits any crime unconsciously it won't be considered as a punishable offence. This is defined by which of the following law? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mc Naughten's rule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McNaughten's rule provides the legal framework for the insanity defense, asserting that an individual who commits a crime while being incapable of understanding the nature or wrongfulness of their actions due to unsoundness of mind cannot be held criminally responsible.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lower segment cesarean section

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of deep transverse arrest with features of CPD, a lower segment cesarean section is the appropriate management to prevent complications and ensure safe delivery.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 661, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is one of the first-line treatments for the acute management of seizures, particularly in status epilepticus. Following the control of immediate seizures with lorazepam, levetiracetam can be used as maintenance antiepileptic therapy.

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

The community has high birth and death rates due to limited healthcare and high disease prevalence. In which stage of the demographic transition model is the birth rate typically the highest? questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Stage 1

  • ➤ Five stages of demographic cycle

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Piriformis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The piriformis muscle is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the branches of the sacral plexus, specifically the ventral rami of S1 and S2. The piriformis muscle plays a role in external hip rotation.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hall-Wellner Band

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.
  • ➤ The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Drowning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text: A man lives with his pregnant wife and a child under 3 years old. His brother and his wife are staying with them for a month. How should this family be categorized? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Nuclear family

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A nuclear family consists of parents and their children, even if other relatives are temporarily staying with them.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.
  • ➤ Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue):
  • ➤ Triangle of Calot (yellow): Upper boundary is the cystic artery. Lateral the cystic duct. Medial the common hepatic duct, CBD Common bile duct.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Insulin Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

  • ➤ Secretagogues: Sulfonylureas, such as glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy due to their mechanism of increasing insulin release from the pancreas.

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is not a complication of? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hepatitis B virus primarily causes hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma, unlike other liver conditions such as parasitic infections, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Caroli's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.correct_answer: B. Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 60-year-old shipyard worker presents with increasing shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough over the past year. He has worked with insulation materials for 35 years. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally. A chest X-ray reveals a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with these findings? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asbestosis is associated with a "ground glass" appearance on chest X-ray and occurs in workers exposed to asbestos over long periods.
  • ➤ Asbestosis

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. L5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The green line marked on the torso corresponds to the L5 vertebral level. This line is also known as the intertubercular plane or Tuffier's line, which is anatomically aligned with the upper border of the L5 vertebra. The intertubercular plane is significant in clinical settings as it passes through the highest points of the iliac crests, located at the L4-L5 intervertebral disc space. This reference point is crucial for procedures such as spinal anesthesia and lumbar punctures, where accurate identification of vertebral levels is essential.
  • • Clinical Significance:
  • • Clinical Significance:
  • • It serves as a reference point for various medical procedures, particularly those involving the lumbar spine, spinal anesthesia, and the placement of lumbar punctures (spinal taps). When performing a lumbar puncture, healthcare providers often use the intertubercular plane as a landmark to identify the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the subarachnoid space. Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century. Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.
  • • It serves as a reference point for various medical procedures, particularly those involving the lumbar spine, spinal anesthesia, and the placement of lumbar punctures (spinal taps).
  • • When performing a lumbar puncture, healthcare providers often use the intertubercular plane as a landmark to identify the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the subarachnoid space. Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century. Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.
  • • Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century. Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.
  • • Tuffier's Line: The term "Tuffier's line" is often used interchangeably with the intertubercular plane. Dr. Paul Tuffier, a French surgeon, introduced this reference point in the early 20th century.
  • • Tuffier's Line:
  • • Variations: It's important to note that individual anatomical variations exist, and the level of the iliac crests can vary among individuals. Therefore, healthcare providers may use additional methods, such as palpation of bony landmarks or radiological guidance, to accurately identify the L4-L5 intervertebral space.
  • • Variations:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. T12: Incorrect as it corresponds to the lower end of the thoracic spine.
  • • Option B. T12:
  • • Option C. L1: Incorrect and typically aligns with the lower border of the first lumbar vertebra.
  • • Option C. L1:
  • • Option D. L3: Incorrect as it corresponds to the subcostal plane, not the intertubercular plane.
  • • Option D. L3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abdominal Planes & Quadrants –
  • ➤ Abdominal Planes & Quadrants –
  • ➤ #2 Horizontal Plane -
  • ➤ Subcostal Plane (L3) Trans tubercular Plane (L5- upper border)

  • ➤ Trans-pyloric Plane of Addison - Lower border of L1
  • ➤ Supracristal Plane - L4

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Thalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.
  • ➤ The thalamic pain syndrome
  • ➤ A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is bitten by a stray dog. She had received post-exposure prophylaxis for a monkey bite two months ago. What is the appropriate management for her current rabies exposure? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Wound care + IM vaccine 0,3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For individuals with a recent history of rabies vaccination (within the past three months), re-exposure prophylaxis includes wound care and two doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: Given the image showing significant limb swelling, which body system is likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lymphatics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Significant limb swelling with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance in the calf region, along with swelling of the foot and squaring of the toes, is a classic presentation of lymphedema, suggesting involvement of the lymphatic system.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in homocystinuria is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cystathionine beta synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the enzymatic basis of homocystinuria, recognizing that the deficiency of cystathionine beta synthase leads to the accumulation of homocysteine and methionine, contributing to the clinical manifestations of the disorder.
